Description: Body fragment from large North Ionian black-figured pottery bowl; interior glazed with two bands of incised ornament with added red and white, tongues and perhaps diamonds above tongues and lotus flowers. Exterior, three friezes; probably floral band at top; broad band above animal frieze set between lines: front parts of two confronted grazing goats with large rosette between; broad band and lower frieze with line at top (at least); part of goat to right preserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 227, no. 133)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 106, pl. XXXIII, no. 316.5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.095)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4661 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
